Bahrain, 2Sth November, 1951. ^ / °/ x !^t) Please refer to your letter (S9/7/51) of the 11th September to Pelly about the boun daries of Sharjah, and in particular about the Shaikh of Sharjah^ claims to Tunb island. - A*/-. 2. As the Residency Agent’s letter 419/1928 referred to in your paragraph 2 was not traceable in the Agency, Pelly asked the Residency whether they could find it in their archives. I have now received a reply from them, a copy of which I enclose for your information. The relevant reference on your files regarding the telegram mentioned in the lest sentence of the letter should be the correspondence ending with Residency Agent's letter No.99 of the 10th April, 1935, to the Political Resident. (W.S. Laver) A.J. Wilton, Esq., Political Officer (Trucial Coast), Sharjah.(1033/33) CONFIDENTIAL /ll+l 38 ? ' ii' +BDITISH ^ESI BAHRAIN. 16th November, 1951 Dear Agency, r &[31 zj !$ i] Your letter 038/3/27/51 of October 3rd. 2 # The history of the ownership of Tunb down to the beginning of this century is conveniently summarised on pages 97 and 98 of P.G.13. To this may be added the statement on page 1908 of Lorrimer Vol. 2. 'Tunb belongs to the Shaikh of Sharjah and is connected with the Has al Khaimah district of his principality.' From these two statements it appears that the ownershio (using the word in its western sense) of Tunb depends at any given moment, on whether Ras al Khaimah is regarded as part of the Shaikhdom of Sharjah or as independent, and we attach a note (written in 1935 ) showing how the ownership of island has passed from one ohaikhdom to the other in the past. 3 # We cannot trace the letter from the Residency Agent enclosed with your letter under reference but it does not appear to be of much 9 value as evidence of ownership of the island. The significance of the fact that permission was sought in 1912 from the Shaikh of Sharjah for the erection of the light-house is mis-interpreted and it is clear that there can now be no question but that we regard the island as belong ing to Ras al Khaimah, (see for example the letter from the Political Resident to the Ruler of Ras al Khaii/ah to which your telegram No.53 of March 28th 1935 to the Senior Naval Officer, Persian Gulf prefers). P.lSb The Political Agency, Bahrain. hlcus-ct Z&fto') l C-. /cl/zi-WI Yours ever, RESIDENCY. See-In/'COPY NOTE ON 0 T -TTEPSHI? OF TUNB. 1750 - 1869 Gazetteer Vol.I Part I, pages 630-633 & 756-9. 1869 -do- P--759. 1900 Town file 14/85 P-51. 1908 Town file p.51. Both Sharjah and Ras al Khaimah were possessions of the Jowasimi clan, the heads of which resided indifferently at either place and were indifferently described as ’’Shaikh of Sharjah” or ’’Shaikh of Ras al Khaimah”. At some periods one Shaikh ruled over both places at others the rulers were separate Shaikhs. Tunb may therefore be described as belonging to the Jowasimi Tribe. Shaikh Humaid bin Abdullah seized administration of Ras al Khaimah proclaimed himself independent of Sharjah and continued so till his death in 1900. Shaikh Humaid bin Abdullah died. Sharjah and Ras al Khaimah reunited under Shaikh Saqar bin Khalid who appointed his son Khalid bin ^aqr as Governor of Ras al Khaimah. (Political Resident to Government of India, letter No.1672, dated the 4-th August 1912). Khalid bin ^aqar died. Shaikh Saqar bin Khalid appointed his (own) uncle Salim bin Sultan to succeed Khalid bin Saqar at Ras al Khaimah who soon set up pretensions to be independent of Sharjah. Shaikh Salim was however never recognised as /..- 2 - / / y - 5. Tovm file 14-/85 p.63. 1912 Conf. Vol T. 11.p.85. A lso Aitchinson Vol. XT. p.258. No.32. 6 . 1919 Town file 14/85.ps.68-9. 7. 1921. -do- p P .70-82. 8 . Gazetteer Vol. II page 1908, ?*> as independent by Government (Political 'hn fJov^mment of India, letter No, 1672, dated the 4-th August 1912). Shaikh Salim died in 1919. The Political Resident obtained the concurrence of Shaikh Saqar bin Kj^alid, ^uler of Sharjah, to the erection of the lighthouse on Tunb Island. Shaikh Salim bin Sultan died and was succeeded by his son Shaikh Sultan bin Salim. Shaikh Sultan bin Salim recognised by Government as Ruler of Has al Khaimah and is still ruling. (Correspondenc ending with Foreign and Political Department Memorandum No.1219 E. A., dated the 21st September 1921, to Political Itesident). Tuhb has been looked upon locally as connected with the Ras al Khaimah district of the Jowasimi Sharjah Principality. Till Ras al Khaimah was definitely recognised as an independent Shaikhdom therefore i.e. not until 1921 can it be said to have become the property of the Ruler of Ras al Khaimah.> COPY G. 10802/31/51 ROXFin^fTIAL. BRITISH EMBASSY, TEHRAH. 12tti May 1951. My dear Hay, V/e have no o'bjection to th.e suggestion ^, 2.3 made in your letter to Furlonge, 182/3/2? of the 14th April that the Shaikh of Sharjah should 'be encouraged to make occasional visits to Abu Musa. I am sending a copy of this letter to Purlonge with reference to his letter to you EA 1081/26 of 1st May. Yours ever, George Middleton. Lieutenant-Colonel Sir Rupert Hay, K.C.I.E. , C. S. WITH THE COMPLIMENTS OF 37433—5r 'JU'/ * At Bahrain. . 0 . 64/1 A. 21 et Larch, Vjjl Sir, I have the honour to forward the attached report of the visit of His Majesty 1 s ship under coom&nd to the island of BU liUSA in connection with the recent visit of a Persian Warship to the island. 2. The report is confined to the Political aspect. Fishing, weather and recreation for the ship’s company will he reported in my routine letter of proceedings. I have the honour to be Sir, Your obedient Servant (Sgd.) Richard Courage CAPTAIK, ROYAL NAVY. The senior Maval Officer, Persian Gulf Appendicesj- A. Report on the island of BU PUSA. i B. Island of BU liUSA - Co^umnicationsQQPi % r .SPO .T a TIE Xi.LA ::p Oi'’ BU i' .UBA. Atinendix A to the Coim.Aiding Oi’i'loer, K. . . Flamingo's letter :;o.61*/1A, dated 21st iarch 1951.; X. Present use or tiie 1 alan d Ox ju The British Golden Valley Colour Company expoi’t about 61 OOO tons of ued Oxide a year. They pay about ,8.35,000 a u onth in wages to their labourers, v/no ai‘e predoi-lnantly Ara. • Ther*e are one or two people of Persian descent, just as t here are in Sharjah, Bubaand other Trucial Coast areas. Mining is carried on by agreement with the Shailth of Sharjah, to whom royalties ai k e paid. A similar arrangement exists for tae island of Sir Bu Ha’air. Mr. Pococh, the fim s representative, is the only European on Bu usa. No mining is carried ouo during the six hotter months. 2. Ownersnio ol' the island. The island is owned by the Shaikh of Sharjah, who also ov/ns the only si op in the one small village. Tat-os nre collected for Sharjah by a Shaikh’s i-ep x k e sent at ive, whose three predecessors ai*e alleged to have recently died natuial deaths in rapid succe .sion. It Is of interet t to note tnat in the year 1906 red oxide was being :ained by a Persian from Lingah (Persia;, who paid royalties of 2f 230 a year* to the Shaikh of Sharjah for the privileges. (Vide Lorlmer s Gazetteer of the Persian Gulf, Vol. XI, page +2 to.* ine i sialic is believed to have belonged to Sharjah for soiae 130 years, so it s present ownersiiip can hardly be in doubt. The Sharjah flag is hoisted on the following occasions:- (a* Whenever a ship arrives. (b) On Fridays. ( c ) on mjecial occasions. By its tattex^d appearance it'was evident that this had been carried out for a number of years. 3 . yisit of per si ah ■arship, . During the forenoon of the 23th February, 1931 n ] ersian '» arshin anchored off the island for about two hours. One ’’Headman 1 ’ (presumably an officer; and fourteen ofcners landed. * o arms were carried. The landing was made at tne siiiall village and enquiries were at once made for someone wno snoke Persian. The Shaikh’s shopkeeper, himself a Persian, then went to meet the officer. The foliowiixg questions and answers appear to have been exchanged 5 •» c . who owns the island ? A. The Shaikh of Sharjah. C . What goes on here f : A. ining by the britiah for six nionthB q year. kr. ococ runs the mine. Q. V^hat flag is tnat ? A. The shaikh of Sharjah’s flag. Q. V^hy, when it should be the Persian flag ? Wu-o hoisted the flag 9 A. A man# n # j v/ant to see the man. f A. He is busy working oomewhe.-e in the :.ine and I can tget hold of him. (It appears that a certain amount of verbal persuasion was used to try and interview the raan who hoisted the flag.) Q* Where are the people who were bom on the island ? A. They are busy wording. A request was then made to visit the so-called shop; this v/as granted. A few sweets were purchased and paid for in Persian money. Q* What iiioney do you use ? A. Indian iupees. Q. The island is Persian and you should be using Persian money. A. he belong to shariah. q. please prepare a place for us as we will probably v/ant to spend the night as .ore here. A. There is no place. The narty then returned on board and the Persian ship sailed and has not returned, ho other messages or instructions were given nor were any census papers left behind. Thera were no incident arid no attempt was r.ade to haul down the flag. not would have happened had the holster been found* I am unable to say. 4 # Other items of interest . (a; As the visit took place on the North West side of the island some three miles from Mr. Pocock's office/residence, he did not hear about it until after it was over. (b) I could not discover the name of the Persian Warship. The shopkeeper t aid it v;as a s.rnll one - much smaller than Flamingo. (c) The eldest son of the Huler of Dubai has visited fu fusa, en route to Persia to hunt. Me was entertained by i,r. Pocock and was apparently Impressed v/ith the activity on the islaud. (d) The present Shaikh of Sharjah is alleged never to have visited his island. 5. conclusions. It appears that the Persian visit took place with the object of making it clear the island belongs to ersia. I doubt if they made any impression on the locals. If Persia intends to pursue the matter she will probably do so in the months when :.r. Pococ.. is away and there is no i/& W/T eo^.iunioation with the outside world. 6. cecommendations. It is recommended that a new flag be provided for <>u Pure. It would also be a good thing if the Shaikh of Sharjah took sore more personal interest in his island. (.^d.; ilchard Coura^o. Dear Wilton, ~/6/- Please refer tc my telegram No.17 of the 17th March about the visit of H.M.S. ’’Flamingo' to Abu Musa. — 2. I enclose copies of the correspondence on the subject which will explain the reason why it was decided not to take the Shaikh of Sharjah to Abu Musa to assert his claim. I should be glad if you could let me have any information you may receive on this subject after the visit of H.M S. 'Flamingo' to the island. Yours sincerely, (L.A.G. Pinhey) A.J. No.2 dated 17th March, 1951. From Political Resident. It has now been decided that Flamingo should not (repeat not) take Shaikh of Sharjah to Bu Musa though I should be grateful if the enquiries mentioned in my telegram of March 15th could still be made. \IV' <3 COPY TELEGRAM PROM FOREIGN OFFICE N0.166 DATED 16th MARCH TO RESIDENCY, BAHRAIN. Addressed to Bahrain telno 166 dated 1 6th March repeated for information to Tehran. p. * Tehran telno 191. In present circumstances, and in view of the action proposed in paragraph 2 of telegram under reference, we agree with paragraph one. See.COPY TELEGRAM CYPHER OTP FROM TEHRAN NO.6 DATED 15th MARCH TO RESIDENCY, BAHRAIN. Following received from Tehran. Begins. Confidential. Addressed to Foreign Office telno 191 of March 14th repeated for information to Bahrain. Your telno 103*'' v ^ ^ ' 1 v*'' * Please see with my telno 190. I agree that S.N.O.P.G. should visit Bu Musa hut I consider that the present moment most inopportune for demonstration of Sharjah’s sovereignty suggested by Bahrain. 2. We have drafted firm letter to the Persian Foreign Minister reasserting Sharjah’s sovereignty which I propose to send as soon as the new Government is settled. F.C. please pass Bahrain as my telno 8.BRITISH RESIDENCY coNyi;>s^viAL 1 6^3/1 6 BAHRAIN 13 th arch, IS51 Sir Rupert Hay would be grateful if you could arrange to send the attached cypher telegram to the senior Havel Officer, Persian Gulf. Perhaps it would be convenient to repeat it to flamingo. (C.:£. Le Quesne) Lt. Commander J. Goatley. I SHOULD BE GRATEFUL IF WHEN FLAMINGO VISITS BU MUSA IT COULD INVESTIGATE EXACTLY WHAT HAPPENED WHEN PERSIAN SLOOP CALLED AND IN PARTICULAR WHETHER IDENTITY CARDS 'WERE DISTRIBUTED.TELEGRAM Cypher Code GTC .Clear From:— AGENCY, BAHRAIN GTC To AGENCY , SHARJAH Despatched Received No. 17 of 17th March, 1951 My c.s. (C22/14/5/51) March 13th. FLAMINGO will not now be calling SHARJAH to take you and the Shaikh to ABU MUSA. Please inform Ruler in whatever terms you think suitable. Letter follows. Confidential. Priority. Following telegram received from Sharjah. Begins: 'Persian sloops visited Abu Musa morning 25th. Anchored off west coast of island for 2 hours. Landing party entered village, questioned shop-keeper regarding ownership of island and nature and pay of labour (gp/undec). No disturbances reported.' Ends. 2. Request appropriate action be taken to ensure that Sharjah's claim to this island is not impaired. = PELLY = Wt. 19849/24 30m. 8.49 Wa. & Co. G51/3. G51/3.—_l j (+ ^H /fez,/3 WITH THE COMPLIMENTS OF HIS MAJESTY’S POLITICAL RESIDENCY BRITISH RESIDENCY, BAHREIN, PERSIAN GULF. 37433—53 P’ 0 'I f . £■, /fo / 2' 2 * STf, J .Vi.,. ,1 . 1 623/3 BRITISH RESIDENCY, BAHRAIN. 8th February, 1951. Dear Chancery, Vve should be interested to learn whether you have heard anything further of the report that the Persian authorities were intending to send a co mission to Bu IRlJ- Musa, which was ^Mentioned in. your telegram No#2 of the • 1 29th January, . \ ^ t/h P 2* have since rec^iveu cuttin> for 1 , ardea with your printed letter Iso.2 (Gl 0802/8/51 ) of the 29th January and both in this extract and in another which has reached us the impression is given that the island was fully occupied by the Persi ms until *'the events of Chahrivar” which presumably means the occupation of Persia by the allied, forces in August 1941* ‘There has so far as we are aware been no active interference by the Persians in the island since 1904. We do not know whether you think any thing should be done to correct the wrong imoression given by the papers. Possibly the less said on the subject the better. 3. The Senior Naval Officer, Persian Gulf is visiting Bu usa on the 8th tebruary in : . . . ' ild Goose ' and we have asked him to ascertain and report whether there have been any signs of Persian interference in the island. As you are probably aware a United kingdom citizen, Mr. Pocock, who is working the red oxide deposits on the island on behalf of his company, usually resides there during the cold weather. 4. Be are sending a copy of this letter to Eastern Department. Yours ever, (1. AVTh. f inhey 1 PIRET, ^GJUIARY. His iViajesty’e Embassy, Tehran. i\rSI ■■■ RESECTED 1623/1 The Political Agent, Bahrain, WITH THE COMPLIMENTS OF HIS MAJESTY’S POLITICAL RESIDENCY 11 British residency, 1 st Peh ruary, 1951* BAHREIN, PERSIAN GULF. 37433—5COPY \ Telegram: Code R (§) From : TEHRAN(via F.O. telno 70 of 29/1/51) To : ' BAHRAIN No. : 2 Date : 29th January, 1951» Restricted. Following received from Tehran. Addressed to Bahrain telno 2 of January 29th repeated for information to Foreign Office. The press today publishes report that the Iranian Government has instructed the authorities in the south to send as soon as possible a commission to Abu Musa to take census of the population and distribute identity cards. The text of the items follows by bag and I will telegraph again if and when I have been able to secure any kind of confirmation. r r - r <f\j ru • GiJpTj ^ rhf e -C ' l 2--2- ^ ■jg INDIA OFFICE RECORDS MI CROFILM

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

physicalDescription.extent: The file’s contents are arranged in reverse chronological order, from the latest item at the front to the earliest at the end. There is a page of file notes at the front of the file (f 2).

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 37; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 3-36; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file comprises correspondence relating to Sharjah’s sovereignty over the islands of Abu Musa [Abū Mūsá] and Tunb, chiefly in response to a Persian challenge to this sovereignty over Abu Musa. The principal correspondents in the file are the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf (Lieutenant-Colonel William Rupert Hay); British Embassy representatives at Tehran; and representatives of the British Navy, including the Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf, and Captain Richard Courage of HMS Flamingo.The file contains:correspondence relating to reports of the visit of a Persian warship at Abu Musa in February 1951, including: initial reports of the intention of Persian officials to visit Abu Musa to take a census of the population and distribute identity cards (f 36); British arrangements to send a vessel to investigate the claims, including discussion of whether the Ruler of Sharjah should accompany them; a report by Captain Richard Courage of HMS Flamingoof his visit to Abu Musa in March 1951, with notes on red oxide mining operations on the island, ownership of the island, the visit of a Persian warship on 25 February 1951, and details of a conversation held between a Persian officer and a shopkeeper on the island (ff 15-17); the Political Resident’s recommendation that the new ruler of Sharjah should visit Abu Musa more frequently;correspondence between the Political Agent at Bahrain (William Scott Laver) and the Political Resident, November 1951, relating to efforts to trace papers on the history of the ownership of Tunb island in the Residency archives. A copy of a note on the ownership of Tunb, undated, is also included (ff 5-6).

name.namePart: Emir of Sharjah, Āl Qāsimī dynasty
Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf
